Bernanke is likely signaling the end of stimulus for 3 reasons:
1. Pricking 2 potential bubbles: the rapid rise in the stock market and bank's addiction to cheap money. The NASDAQ is up over 13% in the last year. Banks have been profiting off of free money instead of lending.
2. Congressional inaction: by cutting instead of investing, Congressional Republicans have had a free ride on the Fed. They get to claim that their cutting is improving the economy, while it is super low rates and QE3.
3. Setting the stage for Yellen: this enables a more pragmatic chair like Yellen to succeed Bernanke because if she gets pinned as a policy dove, then Republicans will have a greater opportunity to block her nomination.

After the initial rise, rates will drop to support a slowly recovering recovery. The stimulus will continue to have its effect.

Does the self-righteous arrogance coupled with the security vs. privacy excuse ring a bell? How about the accusations of giving aid and comfort to the enemy leveled against those who would dare defend civil liberties and challenge the power of the state? The A.P. reporters who exposed this program and won a Pulitzer for their efforts were the victims of the same kind of official castigation that Glenn Greenwald and Edward Snowden and other reporters and whistleblowers are undergoing right now.

In April 2012, then-Obama counterterrorism adviser John Brennan traveled to NYPD headquarters to publicly defend the spy campaign against Muslims. Of course, our leaders proclaim themselves most anxious to forge healthy relationships with the Muslim community even as they give carte blanche to the spying. Sound familiar?

Brennan and the NYPD even urged Muslims to "partner" with the cops to spy on and turn in their friends and neighbors and fellow Mosque congregants. This type of initiative is also being carried over into the new "Insider Threat Program" recently rolled out by the Obama administration. Federal employees are being directed to spy on each and report not just leaking, but such issues as the marital problems and reading habits of their co-workers. Google it.

Both the NYPD and the national Police State should have the book thrown at them. Meanwhile, now more than ever we need a free press to expose the human rights abuses being perpetrated at all levels of government.

Immediately after the Financial Crisis of 2008, housing prices were plummeting. Americans were losing their homes to foreclosure. It was necessary then for Bernanke to cut interest rates to keep the Great Recession from becoming worse.

But housing prices have stabilized and have gone up in most markets. So low interest rates are no longer needed to keep Americans from losing their homes.

According to Krugman, a second reason for low interest rates is to stimulate aggregate demand and fight unemployment. Evidently, Bernanke does not buy that argument quite so much.

In response to Bernanke's words, the rate on 10-year treasuries soared to 2.54% by Friday's close.

We will soon see whether this causes unemployment to go up. My guess is no. And if I'm right, more QE and higher interest rate targets would most likely not affect unemployment either.

What then is the reason for such high unemployment, which cause misery for millions of Americans?

One reason that stands out is too many unskilled workers chasing too few jobs in an economy that needs fewer and fewer unskilled workers.

And Congress is about to make things even worse by approving amnesty for 11 million illegal immigrants, who will start a new wave of immigration competing for scarce American jobs and sinking the lifeboats of the American safety net for its poor.

Even perfect monetary policy is powerless against the onslaught of population growth.

I'm doing some quick research.

First off, the rich are now taxed at a lower official rate than ordinary people because much of their income is taxed at the reduced "capital gains/carried interest" rate, about half the rate we ordinaries pay. That was partially true in the 50s.

Second, what is the actual rate paid in income tax by the rich? I can't find figures right away, but this quotation may help locate serious studies: "time series analyses of top income tax rates since World War II suggest that their decline has had a statistically insignificant impact on economic growth and its driving factors ... the falling top tax rate has had a statistically significant impact both in increasing the share of income concentrated at the very top of the income distribution...."
Read more at http://www.thefiscaltimes.com/Columns/2013/04/10/How-High-Should-Top-Inc...

Third, the rich don't pay FICA, or rather, their payments are such a small percentage income as to be negligible. The very opposite is the case for "us".

I ignore sales taxes, which are a larger percentage of income for those who spend more of their money on purchases and less on investments.

The 50s were not paradise. They simply had less rich rich people and higher official tax rates. And the teens (now) are a paradise for high-income persons.

What I did do however was put away a small portion of my pay constantly. I might have only been $5 a week when I was making $200 a week, but there is the power of compound growth. I have to disagree with Professor Krugman on this one particular issue.

Fed bond buying, which has driven the price of both long- and short-term bonds essentially to zero, has driven capital, including the meager savings of retirees, into higher-risk vehicles like stocks where returns are better.

It has also provided banks an artificially high spread on money borrowed in the USA then flipped in off-shore equity markets.

Corporations are still sitting on a trillion dollars in cash. QE rounds have not made a dent in that.

What is needed to spur employment is fiscal policy -- spending by Congress -- and we will not see that even if hell freezes over.

Want to know what "structural reform" means in the context of Europe's economy? Why not ask Gerhard Schroder? After all, he was the Social Democrat Chancellor who is widely credited with implementing the successful "Agenda 2010" reforms a decade ago in Germany:

http://online.wsj.com/article/SB1000142405270230414120457750853098189322...

For Europe to recover, the rest of the Continent needs to copy the German model, not vice versa.

Once again, Krugman gets everything backwards. He frets about the talk of structural reform becoming "an excuse for not facing up to the reality of macroeconomic disaster" when the real risk is that a narrow-minded focus on ending "austerity" in Europe becomes an excuse to avoid the Schroder-type reforms without which any economic recovery will be short-lived.
